snippet: A finding that epidurals are associated with a longer duration in the second stage of labor indicates that doctors might need to wait more time before intervening with drugs, forceps or cesareans.
abstract: Study published in journal Obstetrics and Gynecology finds that epidurals are associated with an even longer duration in the second stage of labor than is generally recognized; findings suggest that some women may be subject to unnecessary interventions by doctors who wrongly fear labor has become prolonged; determines normal second stage can take as long as 5.6 hours for women who get epidurals during their first births, and as long as 3.3 hours for those who do not.
lead_paragraph: A finding that epidurals are associated with a longer duration in the second stage of labor indicates that doctors might need to wait more time before intervening with drugs, forceps or cesareans.

headline.main: Study Suggests Misplaced Fears in Longer Childbirths
headline.print_headline: Childbirth Study Sees Longer Labor as Normal

keywords.value: American Congress of Obstetricians and Gynecologists
keywords.name: organizations
